useCaseType: Trust & Privacy Negotiation (Sensor Data, Data Sharing)
name: Data Sharing Control Preferences
description: Olivia customizes her ALFRED settings to limit data sharing, ensuring that only essential information is shared with caregivers while maintaining her privacy. This use case addresses her concerns about technology and data safety, allowing her to feel more secure and in control of her personal information.
scenario:
Olivia, a 75-year-old retired social worker, sat in her cozy suburban living room, the warmth of the afternoon sun streaming through the window. She stared at the ALFRED device on the table, a constant reminder of her ambivalence towards technology. It felt overwhelming, like a puzzle with missing pieces. Today, she had decided it was time to confront her privacy concerns head-on by customizing her data-sharing settings. 

“ALFRED, can you help me with my settings?” she commanded, her voice laced with skepticism. ALFRED responded smoothly, “Of course, Olivia. Let’s adjust your data-sharing preferences.” The device’s calm demeanor did little to ease her apprehension. She recalled the many times her late husband had embraced technology without hesitation, while she had always preferred to keep things simple. 

“I want to block all app installations unless I specifically request them,” she said firmly. “And no sharing of my data with anyone, not even my kids or caregivers.” As she spoke, a hint of frustration crept into her voice. ALFRED noted her preferences and began to process them, but Olivia felt the nagging fear of unwanted notifications creeping back in. “And I don’t want any messages unless it’s absolutely necessary!” 

Just then, her caregiver, Mike, called. “Hey Olivia, how’s everything going? I wanted to check in on you through ALFRED today.” His cheerful tone clashed with her need for formality. “I’d prefer not to have any video check-ins, Mike. I’m not comfortable with that,” she replied curtly, feeling her heart race. 

“But Olivia, it’s a great way for me to see how you’re doing. We can adjust the settings if you like,” he suggested, trying to bridge the gap between her needs and his intent to help. 

“Just keep it to offline check-ins, Mike. I don’t want to share too much,” she insisted, her grumpiness bubbling to the surface. The back-and-forth left her feeling drained, a tug-of-war between her desire for independence and the safety net Mike represented. 

As ALFRED confirmed her new settings, Olivia felt a flicker of relief but also a lingering doubt about whether she had made the right choices. She wanted to feel secure and in control, yet technology felt like an intricate web, and she was still unsure if she could navigate it without getting caught.
